info.game_comments:
2001 College Championship quarterfinal game 2.
From the campus at UCLA.

(1, 1).clue: Some of these implements survive from the old copper culture of 5,000 years ago--no bait, though

(3, 1).clue: In 2000 this conference had 3 teams win 10 or more games: Washington, Oregon & Oregon state

(4, 1).clue: We don't know if it was an apple, a kumquat or a banana, but we do know the fruit eve gave Adam was labeled this

(5, 1).clue: After UCLA he went to NYC, then returned to California to star in films like "Rebel Without a Cause"

(6, 1).clue: This ceremony in Tokyo's Keio Plaza Hotel achieves the 4 principles of harmony, respect, purity & tranquility

(1, 2).clue: The SOIC is a society dedicated to remembering these, in which fountain pens & pigtails were dipped

(3, 2).clue: This school's Huskers set a college bowl record by scoring 66 points against Northwestern in the Alamo Bowl

(4, 2).clue: In dissection, use this pincers-like instrument to hold the skin when making an incision

(6, 2).clue: B.R.E.W. stands for the "Rescue, Education & Welfare" of this breed of dog popularized by Charles Schulz

(1, 3).clue: Old Westerners decorated holsters; old Europeans decorated these sword sheaths

(3, 3).clue: The USA's only major undefeated team, it won the national title by beating Florida State in the Orange Bowl

(4, 3).clue: Fodder for cattle, as a verb it means "to plunder"

(5, 3).clue: UCLA grad Ted Stevens helped get this state into the Union & has been its senator for over 30 years

(6, 3).clue: Plant your own bush at the Tranquil Resort near Bangalore, a vacation plantation for this crop

(1, 4).clue: (Jimmy of the Clue Crew pretends to chop at a stone slab.)  I'm wielding the versatile stone-age tool called a hand this, though it lacks a separate blade

(3, 4).clue: Lou Holtz coached this school's Gamecocks to an 8-4 record after a winless season in 1999

(4, 4).clue: (Cheryl of the Clue Crew holds a fluid-filled jar.)  In high school, I just couldn't cut up my frog, so I've still got him--preserved in this

(5, 4).clue: He helped UCLA to two NCAA titles, had a great NBA career & is now a TV commentator

(6, 4).clue: It's from the Latin for "warming"; Whispered Prayers Wicca Store has a 2-gallon one for all your toil & trouble

(1, 5).clue: The guy pictured here is a "dux", latin for "leader", so the medieval coin seen here is called this

(3, 5).clue: A sprained ankle forced this Virginia Tech QB (& Heisman hopeful) to miss 1 game & parts of 2 others during 2000

(4, 5).clue: This 3-named Confederate cavalry general became a leader of the Ku Klux Klan

(5, 5).clue: His "astronomical" success includes creating "90210", "Melrose Place" & "Sex and the City"

(6, 5).clue: Reed's Brew Soda contains a large proportion of this root that is cultivated extensively in Asia & Jamaica

(1, 1).clue: This city was founded in 52 B.C. on the Ile de la Cite, an island in the Seine River

(2, 1).clue: For chapped lips try this brand of petroleum jelly; for dry skin try the Intensive Care lotion

(3, 1).clue: Thomas Jefferson sings!  & so does Sally Hemings in a 2000 opera named for this Virginia residence

(4, 1).clue: When their "MmmBop" reached No. 1 in May 1997, they became the first artists born in the 1980s to have a No. 1 single

(5, 1).clue: Stamps showing a volcano in Nicaragua helped convince Congress to put the canal in this country

(6, 1).clue: Tennyson's poem "Locksley Hall" says, "In" this season "a young man's fancy lightly turns to thoughts of love"

(1, 2).clue: This capital is a port lying on the straits of Florida

(2, 2).clue: The type of this kept in your medicine chest is usually 70% isopropyl or ethyl

(3, 2).clue: "Don Giovanni" tells the tale of the legendary seducer known by this name in Spanish

(4, 2).clue: The first single from her "Butterfly" CD, "Honey" debuted at No. 1 & remained there for 3 weeks

(5, 2).clue: With the end of the war in 1848, this country lost half of its territory to the U.S.

(6, 2).clue: Tennyson met his bosom friend Arthur Hallam while attending Trinity College at this university

(1, 3).clue: In 1898 Lord Kitchener & the British recaptured this African capital from the forces of 'Abd Allah

(2, 3).clue: It's the more common name for acetylsalicylic acid (& it's easier to pronounce)

(3, 3).clue: A 1997 opera (& a Steven Spielberg film) were inspired by the 1839 slave rebellion on this ship

(4, 3).clue: With the 1999 song "Bailamos", he accomplished something his father was unable to achieve--a No. 1 U.S. pop hit

(5, 3).clue: 1 of the 2 agricultural products Cesar Chavez called a boycott of in 1970

(6, 3).clue: In this 1855 poem, there were cannon to the right, left & in front of 600 very unfortunate men

(1, 4).clue: This South American capital is home to the General Bernardo O'Higgins Military School

(2, 4).clue: Isotretinoin, used to treat severe acne, is better known by this trademark name

(3, 4).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew tries to hit a high note wearing a horned helmet and long blonde braids.)  I'm getting dressed for the role of Brunnhilde in "Die Walkure", an opera by this composer"Laaaaaaa!"

(4, 4).clue: In this 1998 hit, No. 1 for 13 weeks, Brandy & Monica sang, "I'm sorry that you seem to be confused, he belongs to me"

(5, 4).clue: This general cleared out the vets camped in Washington, D.C. in July 1932, probably vowing to return if they ever did

(6, 4).clue: In "The Death of" this king, he "shot thro' the lists at Camelot, and charged before the eyes of ladies and of kings"

(1, 5).clue: This Azerbaijani capital might be a contraction of the Persian "bad kube", or "blown upon by mountain winds"

(2, 5).clue: If you tend to nick yourself shaving, keep one of these "pencils" on hand to stop the bleeding

(3, 5).clue: A flop when it debuted in 1904, this Puccini opera set in Nagasaki later became one of the best-loved operas

(5, 5).clue: To keep trains moving during this firm's 1894 strike, mail cars were added, so stopping them was a federal offense

(6, 5).clue: Tennyson succeeded this "Tintern Abbey" poet as Poet Laureate in 1850

(0, 0).clue: It's the body that's about 1 1/4 light-seconds from Earth
